commander.name: Generale Giorgio Carlo Calvi di Bergolo
commander.previous_service: Commanded division from 1 March 1942 through Tunisia Campaign. Repatriated 7 April 1943 after severe casualties at El Guettar. Division subsequently commanded by unknown officers until surrender 13 May 1943.

command.headquarters_location: Tunisia (final defensive positions before Axis surrender)

M14/41.specifications: 47mm L/40 gun, 30mm frontal armor, diesel engine, superior to M13/40

M13/40.specifications: 47mm L/32 gun, 30mm frontal armor, gasoline engine

Semovente 75/18.specifications: 75mm howitzer, self-propelled assault gun on M14/41 chassis

Cannone da 75/27 modello 11.note: Standard Italian divisional artillery, WWI design modernized

Obice da 100/17 modello 14.note: Medium howitzer for indirect fire support

Cannone da 47/32 M35.note: Main Italian anti-tank weapon, inadequate against M4 Sherman by 1943

supply_logistics.supply_status: Critical - Tunisia bridgehead under siege. Axis surrender imminent. Fuel, ammunition, food, and water all critically depleted. Division combat ineffective by early May 1943. Surrender 13 May 1943.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Tunisia - Coastal plains, rocky hills, mixed agricultural and desert terrain

subordinate_units.equipment_summary: 28x medium tanks (M14/41, M13/40), 6x Semovente 75/18 assault guns - severely depleted from Q1 losses
subordinate_units.note: Main armored striking force, critically understrength. Many tanks non-operational due to battle damage and lack of spare parts.

subordinate_units.equipment_summary: Three battalions motorized infantry, severely depleted transport vehicles
subordinate_units.note: Elite light infantry, home station Siena. Reduced to ~70% strength by Q2 1943 after El Guettar casualties.

subordinate_units.equipment_summary: 18x 75/27 field guns, 10x 100/17 howitzers, critically short on ammunition
subordinate_units.note: Home station Trento. Ammunition expenditure limited to conserve remaining stocks.
Divisional anti-tank defense, weapons inadequate against Allied armor by 1943.
Combat engineers with 89th Pioneer Company attached. Focused on defensive preparations.

subordinate_units.equipment_summary: Radio, telephone, motorcycle couriers - many sets inoperative
subordinate_units.note: Divisional communications degraded by equipment failures and Allied air attacks.

subordinate_units.equipment_summary: Heavy trucks for ammunition, fuel, supplies - many destroyed or abandoned
subordinate_units.note: Logistical capability severely degraded. Many vehicles immobilized for lack of fuel.

subordinate_units.equipment_summary: Tank recovery and repair facilities - critically short on spare parts
subordinate_units.note: Unable to maintain tank operational rates due to lack of replacement parts and components.
Traffic control, security, POW handling (CCRR = Carabinieri Reali). Post-surrender, assisted with orderly capitulation.

subordinate_units.equipment_summary: Field ambulances, aid stations - medical supplies critically depleted
subordinate_units.note: Divisional medical support overwhelmed by casualties from earlier battles.

previous_engagements: Battle of El Guettar (March-April 1943) - severely decimated

casualties_current_quarter.note: Entire surviving division captured at Axis surrender 13 May 1943. Total Q2 casualties include combat losses April-May plus entire remaining strength entering POW camps.

historical_notes.formation_history: Formed 1939 as one of Italy's original three armored divisions (131st Centauro, 132nd Ariete, 133rd Littorio). Named after the mythological Centaur. Stationed Albania June 1940, fought in Greece and Yugoslavia 1940-1941.
historical_notes.tunisia_deployment: Sent to North Africa November 1942 after Allied victories at El Alamein. Division arriving in stages to bolster Axis Tunisia bridgehead. Part of Italian First Army defensive operations.
historical_notes.q2_1943_situation: By April 1943, division severely weakened from Battle of El Guettar (March-April) where it was 'severely decimated' per US intelligence. General Calvi di Bergolo repatriated 7 April after heavy casualties. Division combat ineffective by early May, reduced to ~6,200 personnel from authorized 9,200+.
historical_notes.final_operations: Division participated in final defensive battles of Tunisia Campaign (April-early May 1943). Tank strength reduced to 28 tanks (18 operational) from original 52+. Critical shortages of fuel, ammunition, spare parts rendered division largely immobile. Surrendered with Axis forces 13 May 1943.
historical_notes.axis_surrender_tunisia: On 13 May 1943, all remaining Axis forces in Tunisia surrendered to Allied forces. Centauro Division personnel (approximately 6,200 survivors) entered POW camps. This marked end of division's combat history.
historical_notes.post_surrender: Division formally disbanded. Survivors spent remainder of war in Allied POW camps (North Africa, then transferred to camps in USA, UK, or other Allied territories). Division name and lineage preserved for post-war reconstitution.

tank_operational_status.reason: No detailed April-May 1943 strength returns available. Estimated from Q1 1943 baseline minus Battle of El Guettar losses and maintenance degradation.
sources_checked: US Army G-2 Order of Battle July 1943
tank_operational_status.estimate_method: Linear degradation from Q1 1943 levels accounting for combat losses, mechanical attrition, and lack of spare parts. Tank strength estimated at ~60% of Q1 levels.

subordinate_commanders.reason: No individual commander names identified for Q2 1943. General Calvi di Bergolo repatriated 7 April 1943. Subsequent division commander not identified in available sources.
sources_checked: US Army G-2 Order of Battle July 1943
Italian Army Lists (if available for this period)
subordinate_commanders.mitigation: Ranks confirmed from Italian divisional TO&E structure. Positions existed but individual names not documented.

detailed_casualties.reason: Only aggregate division casualties available. Unit-level casualty breakdown not found in sources. Captured personnel count derived from total surviving strength at surrender.
detailed_casualties.estimate_method: Total Q2 casualties calculated from: (Q1 ending strength) - (Q2 combat losses) - (Q2 ending strength at surrender). Captured count = surviving personnel at 13 May 1943 surrender.
